Entry.3:
Reveille at 3.30 am. Returned blankets to Q.M. store 5am breakfast.6am marched from Maribyrnong Camp to Ascot Vale station arriving there about 7am.

Special train to Port Melb. Stopped at Flinders St Station for about 15 min. arrived Port Melb. Bout 8am.

Embarked on H.M.T.S."BORDA" (A30) at 10 am, and allotted to tables, stored our kits, then allowed on deck.

Our friends were not allowed on the 

Pier till 12.50pm and as we sailed at 1pm we had not much time to say good-bye.

After leaving Melb. We got paid for the few days that was due for the time in camp, as we start afresh on board.

 Arrived off Queenscliff about 6.30 pm and lay there for about an hour. Paymasters’ disembarked and mails sent ashore.

We then sailed through the Heads and about 10pm the lights of Australia disappeared. 

After a very pleasant voyage, we sighted land at 10.15am on the
Entry.4:
Always to the front the Y.M.C.A. welcomed us at Port O’Call No1 (Durban) even before the ship was made fast.

From far out on the Jetty a young lady Semaphored the greetings of the ubiquitous and ever helpful institution. Come to the Y.M.C.A. Hut close to the Town Hall.

Arrived in Wharf at 12 noon but were not allowed ashore till a guard of 50 Artillery men

went to the goal and brought back about twenty Australians (who had deserted from previous ships) and were safely lodged in the Guard room. 

At 3.45pm, we disembarked and marched to the Town Hall (about
Entry.5:
mls. from wharf) 

We were then dismissed and granted leave til11pm, that night. This Port O’Call was the soul of hospitality towards us.

There was however a humiliating exception namely, that the use

of hotels was rigorously barred against us.

This humiliation was bequeathed to us by our own countrymen (Australians) who had gone on before us.

It was simply an absolutely necessary precaution, taken by the town people amongst whom we found ourselves, against the repetition of sheer madness perpetrated by the men of earlier troopships. But the closing of the hotels did not keep some of the 

boys from getting a drink. At Durban one of the printing forms presented the ship with a printing press and all accessories, for printing a paper on board (called The Log of the Lunatic Ship).

When we were dismissed at the Town Hall, I think most of the Boys made for tracks for a good feed, and I can safely say that they did enjoy it, after the ships tucker.

Then went for a Ricksha ride round

town, and after that a circular tram ride to the zoo. Tram are free to soldiers in uniform, and when we were returning to the ship at night they had special trams waiting for us.

Arriving on board at 11pm.

The next day
Entry.6:
we had not finished coaling, so we were marched into the city arr. there about 10am, and granted leave till 2pm that day. Visited the zoo

Where the Ladies of Durban were entertaining wounded soldiers, who were returning to Australia by the hospital ship “Karoola". About 1pm we returned to the city and paid the Y.M.C.A. a visit, where we had a splendid tea, consisting of Fish Salad, bread and butter, Tea and as much fruit as we could eat for the small sum of four pence.

After taking a few photographs I returned to the boat

at 2pm, but did not sail till 5.15pm.

Before we sailed the Ladies were handing baskets full of oranges and pineapples to the Boys.

The Boys all enjoyed themselves at Durban and would have liked to have spent a few more days there.

The first day out from Durban we had it very rough but as all the Boys had their “Sea Legs" by this time, it did no effect them in any way.

Reveille at 6.30am

Roll call 7am

Breakfast 7.30am

General Parade 9.30am

Retreat 11.30am

Dinner 12 noon

Parade again 2pm

Retreat 4pm

Tea 4.30pm

Hammock parade and roll call 5.30pm

First Post 9pm

Last Post 9.30pm

Lights out 9.45pm

Between Port Melbourne and Durban (only) Life boat drill, signalled by one long and three short blasts on the steam siren.

It was so rough that the ship was only doing about two knots per hour, and the sea was breaking over the forecastle. 

Kept in sight of land, till we reached Capetown, when we sighted the lights at 7.30pm on Nov.13th.

We lay off in the Bay till the next morning (14thNov.) when the ship made fast in the Wharf at 6.30am.

No leave granted, as the Capetown medical officer said that we had a case of

Meningitis on board, but the ships Doctor said that it was nothing of the kind, any way the ship was isolated.

The general opinion on board was that it was a tale put up by the shore officials to keep the Boys on the ship, as some of the previous ship’s with Australians had played up and had destroyed a few places (hotels).

In the afternoon we were allowed to go for a route march.
Entry.7:
Route march in the morning, and back in time for dinner.

After dinner we were marched to the oval where we had sports, Tea and cakes provided by the Ladies of Capetown.

About 5 O’clock we marched to the Feather Market where the Y.M.C.A. provided us with Tea, scones, cakes and fruit, then a concert after, but I don’t think many of the Boys remained

as they were anxious to see the city.

There was a guard at the entrance to prevent us going out, but the Boys we in a body and of course the guard was helpless.

After leaving the Feather Market I boarded a tram at the Statin in Adderley St. and went for a circular trip to Camp’s Bay, (said to be the finest tram ride in the World) eleven miles round the “Lions Head" (A high peak alongside Table Mountain)

The car goes up Adderley St. over the Kloof Nek, along The Twelve Apostles, rising 700 ft. above sea level, and down into Camp’s Bay.

The fare for the circular journey with break at Camp’s Bay is one shilling for Australians and New Zealanders in khaki.

The actual time taken is one hour twenty minutes.

The trip affords a fine panoramic

View of Capetown and the Suburbs.

On approaching the Nek the “Devils Peak" may be seen on the left above Groote Schuwr and the Lions Head on the right.

Over the Nek, on the shoulder of the “Lions Head" are the famous Silver Trees, while the Apostles extend on the left.

Camp’s bay is said to be the prettiest Watering Place in the Cape Peninsular.

There we visited the Warmed sea water swimming bath, but were unable to get a dip as the baths were reserved for clubs that day. (Mixed bathing too)

Any other time the Attendant will admit you and give you the use of a costume and towel, free of charge.

After coming out of the Baths the Ladies provide Tea and a cake free between the hours of 2 and 5 pm

to all Australians and N. Zealand soldiers, in the Tea rooms called the Old Pagoda under the Pines.

Should you wish to write to your friends at home the Ladies will provide you with all necessary writing materials.

A very enjoyable afternoon may be spent at Camp’s Bay.

We had hard luck as it was getting dark

when we arrived there, and were too late for Tea.

We then returned to the city via Sea Point, and by the time we had a walk round town and visited the great Promenade Pier, it was time to return to the boat.

We had to pass the Feather Market on our way to the ship and the Boys were just coming out of the Hall, so our party joined in with them and

marched back to the “Borda" and got on board without any trouble.
Entry.9:
As we are now entering the danger zone, no lights are allowed on deck, and all port holes are covered.

Finals of Tug o’ War today, and there was great excitement among 

our Boys when Artillery won.

Nov.24th Friday

Crossed the “Line" this morning about 6am.

Smoking allowed only in the Well deck, and we have to go into the Washhouse to light up.

Nov.25th (Saturday)

Orders issued that no smoking allowed on any part of the ship after dark, and that

We have to talk very quietly.

The Boys have all been wondering what’s doing as the ship has been changing her course nearly every hour.

Nov.26th (Sunday)

Every man to carry a lifebelt.

Sighted land at 6pm. (Freetown Sierra Leone. British West Africa).

Arrived in bay about 7pm

Lay off in Bay until next morning

Entry.10:
About 10 am we went ashore in the ships boats, pulled by a small steam tug.

Granted leave till 3pm.

Had a good ramble round town visited Victoria Park, and the only White people to be seen about the place is the Government officials, and a few store keepers.

The rest are all blacks.

It is a very interesting place, and one particular thing I noticed is that the streets are not formed.

They seem to be only beaten tracks.

After walking about for two hours we began to feel hungry, but could not find a Café so we bought lemonade and biscuits at the store.

While eating them the Blacks kids were round us like bees, cadging

biscuits.

We then visited the fruit market and bought some fruit, then made our way to the Wharf.

Going back to the ship we were so crowded in the barge, that by the time we got on “Borda" our clothes were saturated with perspiration.

Then there was a great rush for the bathrooms for cold showers, and change of clothes before tea.

We did not get any more leave during our stay in Sierra Leone.

While lying in the Bay the natives came alongside every day in canoes and rowing boats selling fish and fruit (Oranges 24 for 1 shilling, Bananas 1 shilling per doz, Coconuts 3pence each, Limes 3 pence per doz).

The Boys were greatly amused by the natives diving for silver.

The Saturday before leaving Freetown we had to take 60 sailors on board from the H.M.S.King Alfred.

The sailors were reserves, and were going to England.

We had also to take 450 men (Australian Soldiers) from the Port Lincoln on board, as their ship had run onto a sand bank at the mouth of the Harbour, and had strained her plates in her effort to get off.

As our boat carried on thousand, five hundred (1500) troops before, and with these extra 600 coming on board, we are now packed like sardines.

A certain number of the Port Lincoln troops, were allotted to each Transport and the remainder were sent to the barracks ashore.

During our stay here it was very hot, the temperature ranging from100 degree to 110 degree in the shade, and we were

all glad when we weighed anchor at 4.35 pm on
Entry.11:
and thought we had seen the last of this Hell as the Boys called it.

After being a little over three days sail from Sierra Leone and just beginning to get into the cool climate when we received a wireless massage ordering our boat back to Sierra Leone.(It was rumered that the German Raider was not far off about 10 miles) 

We turned back about 2 am on
Entry.12:
When the Boys got out of bed in the morning and found out, that they wee returning to Sierra Leone, they did enjoy themselves.

The language was something awful.

We arrived back at Freetown about 2 pm
Entry.13:
to find that the other Transports has also returned.

There were now about 30 ships in the bay including two French cruisers.

As the “Borda" has not coaled since leaving Capetown her supply is getting very low, and as labor if scarce we have all been detailed to assist in the coaling of the ship, when the collier comes alongside.
Entry.14:
Five or six Troopships left the bay this

afternoon about 3.30 with escort of Auxilary Cruiser Marmura (Pand O) and French cruiser Duflex. Said to be going to Dakar for Guns.

Our ship has to stay behind as we have not coaled yet.
Entry.15:
Collliers came alongside this morning about 7am and the first shift of 34th Infantry started at 8.30am (64 men from each unit)

They were nice and clean when they

Went down the hold of the collier, but what a difference when they finished their shift of 3 ½ hours.

They were as black as niggers.

Nevertheless the 34th Infantry tore in and put up a fine performance.

There we followed by the first team of Field Artillery, who suffered from a shortage if bags.

The 33rd next went into the fray. They were practically unhampered throughout

and topped all other scores by many tons averaging 41 tons per hour.

Great grafters the 33rd.

The 35th put in a good performance and would have bettered it by many toms had they not been without lights for 1 ¼ hours.

The 36th only worked 2 hours 35 mins, but averaged 43 ¾ tons per hour during that time.

The
Entry.16:
Pioneers put up a great effort and finished in third place.

The second team of Artillery suffered

From jammed bunkers; the 37th and T.M.R. also suffered this disability.

Finishing was done by the 39th, the most awkward coaling shift next the opening one.

F.A.2nd team 67

37th Inf. 64

T.M.B.and A.S.C.60

The Admiralty, so runs the tale, asked skipper if he could get 850 tons on board I 48 hours.

He replied it could be done in 36 hours a statement which was received with polite incredulity.

Well; it was done in 28 ½ hours, and everybody concerned can be very proud of the performance.

John and I were in the second shift of the F.A.3 till 6am.Trousers, white hat and boots

were all the clothes we had on.

We had to fill 2cwt. Bags, and whenever we had ten filled they were hauled up by the ships wenches.

Six men in each corner of the hold two holding the bags and (4) four filling.

At first I did not like the job but soon got used to it. The dust was something awful, and we were not very long in the hold before we were

as black as the coal and we could only recognise one another by their voice.

During this shift they called for five volunteers to go into the Bordas bunkers to relieve the firemen in clearing the shoots, as we had been sending the coal down so quick that they got chocked.

John and I volunteered, and when we got down below the dust was so thick that we could hardly see our hand

In front of us. I was jolly glad when I got out of it, and back to the collier.

At 6am we finished our shift and then there was a great rush for the baths and we had to use a scrubbing brush to get the black off.

After getting nice and clean, one of the Boys, who had not washed, would either hug, or brush up against you, and you had to start again

with the scrubbing brush.

Nothing of any importance happened during the remaining few days of our stay at Freetown.
Entry.18:
Artillery mounted guard at 6pm.

Finished guard at 6pm next day (Xmas)
Entry.19:
Had a great dinner (I don’t think)

Leg of Lamb and a small piece of greasy pudding.
Entry.20:
Dec.16

Great cheering when we sailed away from Sierra Leone at 10.30am.

I reckon if we had remained much longer at Lierra Leone, the Borda, would have been a Hospital Ship as some mornings between three and four hundred were up before the Doctors.

The Hospitals were full and dozens of the Boys were walking about with Mumps, unable to

to get into the Hospital.

The H.M.S. Kent, Durham Castle, City of Sparta, and the Marathon left at the same time, and when we got out of the Bay we got into the following formation.

Diagram drawn showing position of these 5 ships in one,two,two formation H.M.S Kent leading and Borda in the second two

 

About 8.30 this morning we sighted five Transports, Auxilary Cruiser, and French Warship.

At 9.30am we started going round in a circle as we had to wait until the other ships made up to us and it was a great sight watching the manoeuvers of all the boats getting into line.(These were the transports that left Sierra Leone a few days before us, to get guns at Dakar)

 

The following is the formation that we got into, and kept on our way to England

Diagram drawn showing one, three, three, three formation H.M.S.Kent continues to lead.

After getting into this formation the French Warship and the Auxilary Cruisers left us.
Entry.21:
Jan.1917

Very quiet day. The last few days we have been put on half rations and we never get enough to eat. No use complaining to the Orderley Officer. Stew for breakfast, Soup, Roast and rice for dinner no potatoes or any kind of vegetables, Bread and butter for tea, occasionally a little cold meat.

Tucker very poor, and sometimes unfit to eat
Entry.22: About 4pm the H.M.S.Kent left us then the Transports all went separate routes. At five o’clock 10 destroyers came alongside but only two remained, the remainder going with the other transports.
Entry.23:
Very rough we have to hang on to the rails, as it is impossible to stand without holding on to something.

About 8.30pm we sighted the first lighthouse in England
Entry.24:
Arrived in Plymouth at 4am .Disembarked at 2pm. Taken ashore by the S.S.Sir Walter Raleigh.

Left Plymouth at 4.15pm by corridor train (G.W.R.) John and I and four others had a lovely first class compartment. At Exeter we were provided with Tea and buns by the ladies. All blinds have to be kept down on case of Zep. Raids, Very little

light in the station and the lamp glasses are painted black.

At 10.30pm we arrived at Tedworth. Then we had a four mile march to Park-house Camp Salisbury Plain.

Arriving there about 12 midnight.

We were kept out in the cold till nearly 2am as they had not arranged for our coming. Then we had to be issued with blankets (four).

We were then put into a hut (40men). About 3am our biscuits and tinned meat, arrived from the Station, and we did enjoy them as we had nothing to eat after 12o’clock dinner on the “Borda" except the bun that we had at Exeter.

Wed.10thJan17

Did not get out of bed till 9am as we were all so tired after our march the night before.

No parades so have just been walking about Camp. Snow on ground this morning.
Entry.25: After dinner walked to the village of Shipton, it is the right old English style. Thatched roofs and a creek running alongside the main street.
Entry.26:
Route march this morning and after dinner snow started

to fall and all the Boys were crowding round the windows watching it fall. Great excitement but none went outside it see it. It was too cold.
Entry.27:
One of the Artillery Boys who had Mumps on board “Borda" and was sent into the Devonport Hospital returned last night and was allotted to our hut. 

As he did not feel too good he went

To the Doctor this morning.

He was sent into the Hospital with measles, and all the Boys in the Hut (No24) were isolated.

We were taken off the Parade ground and sent into the hut, and not allowed to mix with the other men.

I don’t think the Boys mind, as they will get out of the long route marches.
Entry.28:
Left Parkhouse Camp this morning at about 11am and had a seven or eight mile march to Larkhill Camp.

Arrived at Larkhill about dinner time ans ther was a good dinner of roast beef, potatoes and cabbage waiting for us.

Measley mob visited the Doctor to see if we could get out of isolation

but no luck. Were told to stay in hut.
Entry.29: Heavy fall of snow (about 6 inches). The Boys from the Isolation went out and had a good snow fight.
